body.p: The purpose of this activity is to explore the effectiveness of randomization in creating similar treatment groups, in the sense that it balances the groups with respect to other variables that we didn't control for.

A local internet service provider (ISP) created two new versions of its software, with alternative ways of implementing a new feature. To find the product that would lead to the highest satisfaction among customers, the ISP conducted an experiment comparing users' preferences for the two new versions versus the existing software.

The ISP ideally wants to find out which of the three software products causes the highest user satisfaction. It has identified three major potential lurking variables that might affect user satisfaction—gender, age, and hours per week of computer use.
In this activity, we will use adults in a hypothetical city as the population of interest to the ISP. We will:

ul.li: create a simple random sample as the basis for the experimental study of the population,
use randomization to assign individuals to treatment groups, and
verify that randomization prevented the three treatment groups from being different with respect to the most obvious lurking variables.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the dataset preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.

The data have been loaded into the data frame computers. The data frame has three variables: age, gender, comp. This dataset has more than 20,000 entries, so we will not display it. To verify that the data have been loaded into the variable computers, copy the following command to R:

You can see information about the age of the population and the number of hours (comp) per week that the subjects use computers. You also see that there are more than 10,000 men and more than 10,000 women in the population (gender).

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open this file in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click hereto open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link “Open StatCrunch” at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the data set choose Data -> Load -> From file -> on my computer.
Select the "Browse" or “Choose File” (depending on which browser you're using and select the data set you downloaded
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on “Load File”

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To open Minitab with the population data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: a dialog box will likely appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click "OK."

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: To open a group of lists with the gender, age, and computer use data loaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and send it to your calculator. For instructions on how to connect your calculator to your computer and transfer a file, click here.
In order to see all of the lists in table format on your TI calculator, you'll need to create three extra lists, called AGE3, GEND3, and COMP3. For a reminder of how to do this, click here.

body.p: Our dataset contains the values of the three possible lurking variables:

ul.li: age: in years
gender: female or male
comp: hours per week of computer use

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: The company must rely upon sampling to study its customers' preferences, since the entire population cannot be assigned to treatments. Therefore, we will first choose a simple random sample (SRS) of 450 people for the subjects in the study.
To choose the sample, copy the following command to R:
Again, we do not wish to view all 450 entries in the random sample. Instead, let's look at a summary of the sample by copying the following command:
By looking at the numbers of males and females in the sample, we see that the sample indeed has 450 entries.

Now we will randomly assign our SRS of 450 subjects to treatment groups, one for each of the three versions of the ISP's software. Let's denote the versions "1," "2," and "3," and create a categorical variable to identify the treatment for each subject.
To use R to randomly assign the 450 subjects to one of three treatments, copy the following command:

Note: Using R—The variable group is a list of 450 randomly chosen values from 1, 2, and 3. You can see them by entering the variable name group into R. These commands add a fourth column to the variable random_sample. The four columns are age, gender, comp and group.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: The company must rely upon sampling to study its customers' preferences, since the entire population cannot be assigned to treatments. Therefore, we will first choose a simple random sample (SRS) of 450 people for the subjects in the study.
To do this in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose: Data → Sample Columns
Select columns: Age, Gender, Comp
Sample size: 450
Check: Sample all columns at one time
Store samples: Split across columns
Press: Press Compute!

alternative.p: Note that three columns are added called: Sample(Age), Sample(Gender), Sample(Comp)

Now we will randomly assign our SRS of 450 subjects to treatment groups, one for each of the three versions of the ISP's software. Let's denote the versions "1," "2," and "3," and create a categorical variable to identify the treatment for each subject.
To do this in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose: Data → Simulate Data → Discrete Uniform
Enter Rows: 450, Columns: 1, Min:1 and Max: 3
Store values: Split across columns
Press: Compute!

alternative.p: You’ll see a new column of data (called Discrete Uniform 1) with the randomized treatment groups. To rename this column: first select the heading (i.e. “Discrete Uniform 1”) and press the Delete key and then type: “Treatment” for the new column name.

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: The company must rely upon sampling to study its customers' preferences, since the entire population cannot be assigned to treatments. Therefore, we will first choose a simple random sample (SRS) of 450 people for the subjects in the study.
To do this in Minitab:

ul.li: Choose: Calc → Random Data → Sample From Columns...
Enter "450" to indicate the requested size of the random sample.
In the next text box enter "Age Gender Comp" to indicate the variables we are sampling.
Next to "Store samples in:" type "AgeSRS GenderSRS CompSRS".
Click "OK".
You'll see three new columns of data.

alternative.p: Now we will randomly assign our SRS of 450 subjects to treatment groups, one for each of the three versions of the ISP's software. Let's denote the versions "1," "2," and "3," and create a categorical variable to identify the treatment for each subject.
To do this in Minitab:

ul.li: Choose: Calc → Random Data → Integer...
Enter "450" to indicate the number of subjects we need to assign to treatments.
Next to "Store in column(s):" type "Treatment".
Next to "Minimum value:" enter "1". Next to "Maximum value:" enter "3".
Click "OK".
You'll see a new column of data with the randomized treatment groups.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: The company must rely upon sampling to study its customers' preferences, since the entire population cannot be assigned to treatments. Therefore, we will first choose a simple random sample (SRS) of 450 people for the subjects in the study.
To do this in Excel:

ul.li: Pick 4 empty columns in your Excel worksheet and label them RandomNumber, Age_SRS, Gender_SRS, and Comp_SRS.

In the RandomNumber column, type this formula in row 2: =RAND(). Then copy and paste the formula into each cell in the column from row 3 down to row 20784. This generates a random number in each cell of the column.

IMPORTANT: For a large cell range you can make this easier by doing the following: first copy the contents from row 3, next select the range of cells by first selecting the cell directly below the random number and then pressing F5. At the bottom of the menu that appears, type the column letter and 20784 in the reference line. For example, if your random numbers appear in column G you would type G20784. Hold shift and click OK to select all the cells. Finally, paste the contents that you copied.
Type Control-A twice to select all of the data in the worksheet, and then choose Sort & Filter → Custom Sort from the Editing group in the Home tab.
In the pop-up window, make sure that My data has headers is checked and then choose RandomNumber from the pull-down menu next to Sort by. Click OK.

Now select all of the data in rows 2-451 under the columns that contain the original variables (Age, Gender, Comp), and copy and paste those data into the new columns you created (Age_SRS, Gender_SRS, and Comp_SRS).

alternative.p: Now we will randomly assign our SRS of 450 subjects to treatment groups, one for each of the three versions of the ISP's software. Let's denote the versions "1," "2," and "3," and create a categorical variable to identify the treatment for each subject.
To do this in Excel:

ul.li: Pick an empty column in your Excel worksheet and label it Treatment.

In the Treatment column, type this formula in row 2: =RANDBETWEEN(1,3). Then copy and paste it into each cell in the column from row 3 down to row 451. This generates a random integer from 1 to 3 in each cell of the column.
Select the entire column of random numbers that you just created, right-click on the column and choose Copy, and then right-click on the column again and choose Paste Special .
In the pop-up window, choose Values under Paste, and click OK.
Type Control-A twice to select all of the data in the worksheet, and then choose Sort & Filter → Custom Sort from the Editing group in the Home tab.
In the pop-up window, make sure that My data has headers is checked and then choose Treatment from the pull-down menu next to Sort by. Click OK.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: The company must rely upon sampling to study its customers' preferences, since the entire population cannot be assigned to treatments. Therefore, we first chose a simple random sample (SRS) of 450 people for the subjects in the study.

Now we will randomly assign our SRS of 450 subjects to treatment groups, one for each of the three versions of the ISP's software. Let's denote the versions "1," "2," and "3," and create a categorical variable to identify the treatment for each subject.
To do this on your TI graphing calculator:

ul.li: Choose MATH/PRB/5:randInt(
Next to lower: type in 1.
Next to upper: type in 3
Next to n: type in 450
Highlight Paste and hit ENTER.
Since we want to assign each of the 450 individuals in SRS to one of three treatment groups, we want to generate 450 random numbers between 1 and 3.
You should see:
This indicates that the first individual should be assigned to treatment 2, the second also to treatment 2, the third to treatment 3, the fourth to treatment 1, and so on for all 450 individuals.
To make this easier on the TI, we can store the random numbers in a list by giving the command to store (STO>) either before or after we generate the random numbers:
Before: MATH/PRB/5:randInt(1,3,450)/STO>/L1/ENTER
Before:
After:
After: MATH/PRB/5:randInt(1,3,450)/ENTER
STO>/L1/ENTER Note: When you hit the STO> as first thing on line, it assumes you want to store the last answer (Ans).

Since the process of actually moving each data value for each of the 450 individuals into nine lists (age1, age2, age3, gender1, gender2, gender3, comp1, comp2, comp3) is tedious, we took a random sample, did the sorting, and have the 9 lists ready to download.
L1: age for individuals in treatment 1
L2: gender for individuals in treatment 1 (1 = Female, 2 = Male)
L3: comp (hours per week of computer time) for individuals in treatment 1
L4: age for individuals in treatment 2
L5: gender for individuals in treatment 2 (1 = Female, 2 = Male)
L6: comp (hours per week of computer time) for individuals in treatment 2
AGE3: age for individuals in treatment 3
GEND3: gender for individuals in treatment 3 (1 = Female, 2 = Male)
COMP3: comp (hours per week of computer time) for individuals in treatment 3

body.p: We are finally reaching the goal of this activity. We will now examine whether the randomization was successful in making our three treatment groups similar with respect to the variables age, gender, and comp. In other words, we will now examine whether the distributions of these variables in the three groups are similar or not.
To compare the distribution of age among the three treatment groups, we'll create side-by-side boxplots of age by treatment.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: Copy the following command to R:

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose: Graphics → Boxplot
Select the column Sample(Age)
Group by Treatment
Select “Plot groups for each column”
Press Press Compute!

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Minitab:

ul.li: Choose: Graph → Boxplot → One Y With Groups, and click "OK".
Tell Minitab that you want to graph the variable AgeSRS, and that the categorical variable for grouping is Treatment.
Click "OK".

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Excel, we first have to create a table of descriptive statistics:

ul.li: To create this table, first make the row and column labels: in an empty section of your worksheet, pick a cell and type Statistic. Then move one cell to the right and type Treatment 1. Move one cell to the right and type Treatment 2, and then another cell to the right and type Treatment 3. Now, in the cell underneath Statistic, type min. Move down one cell and type Q1, then underneath that Median, then Q3, and finally Max.

alternative.p: Now for each statistic, we'll enter the formula to calculate that statistic and the range of data that corresponds to each variable:

ul.li: In the cell to the right of min and underneath Treatment 1, type =min([range]), where [range] represents the data in the Age_SRS column that has a Treatment value of 1.
Now move one cell to the right (so that you're underneath Treatment 2 ), and type =min([range]) where [range] represents the data in the Age_SRS column that has a Treatment value of 2.
Repeat this calculation for Treatment 3, again adjusting the data range appropriately.

IMPORTANT: Instead of typing the [range] inside of the parentheses, it is better to highlight the relevant cells with your mouse after typing =min( (by holding a left click as you highlight the cells).

In the cell to the right of Q1 and underneath Treatment 1, type =quartile([range],1), where [range] represents the data in the Age_SRS column that has a Treatment value of 1. Repeat for Treatments 2 and 3, adjusting the data range appropriately each time.

In the cell to the right of Median and underneath Treatment 1, type =median([range]), where [range] represents the data in the Age_SRS column that has a Treatment value of 1. Repeat for Treatments 2 and 3, adjusting the data range appropriately each time.

In the cell to the right of Q3 and underneath Treatment 1, type =quartile([range],3), where [range] represents the data in the Age_SRS column that has a Treatment value of 1. Repeat for Treatments 2 and 3, adjusting the data range appropriately each time.

In the cell to the right of Max and underneath Treatment 1, type =max([range]), where [range] represents the data in the Age_SRS column that has a Treatment value of 1. Repeat for Treatments 2 and 3, adjusting the data range appropriately each time.

alternative.p: Unfortunately, Excel can't create boxplots directly, so we have to create a column graph and alter it so that we get boxplots. We start by using our Descriptive Statistics to create a new table that will be the basis for our column graph:

ul.li: Right below the cell labeled Max in your Descriptive Statistics table, type 25th Percentile . Move down one cell and type 50th Percentile , then underneath that 75th Percentile, then Lower limit , and finally Upper limit.

The 25th Percentile values are the same as those for Q1, so select the values for Q1, right-click and select Copy, and then select the empty cells in the 25th Percentile row and right-click and select Paste Special. In the pop-up window, choose Values and click OK.

The 50th Percentile values are equal to Median - Q1 , so enter the necessary formulas to calculate those values from the values in your Descriptive Statistics table. For example, if the value for Treatment 1 Median is in cell M4, and the value for Treatment 1 Q1 is in cell M3, the correct formula for calculating the 50th percentile for Treatment 1 would be =M4-M3.
The 75th Percentile values are equal to Q3 - Median.
The Lower limit values are equal to Q1 - min.
The Upper limit values are equal to Max - Q3.

alternative.p: Now we can finally create our boxplots:

ul.li: Highlight the values in the 25th Percentile, 50th Percentile, and 75th Percentile rows, and then choose Column in the Charts group on the Insert tab.
In the pull-down menu, choose the second option under 2-D Column (labeled Stacked Column if you hover your mouse over it).

Excel will create a stacked column graph for you. The idea here is that the top two boxes in each column will make up our boxplots. We'll add error bars for the min and Max values, and simply remove the bottom box.
Click on the top box in one of the columns to select it, and then choose Error Bars → More Error Bars Options in the Analysis group on the Layout (Chart Tools) tab.
In the pop-up window, choose Vertical Error Bars on the left and then choose Plus on the right.
Choose Custom under Error Amount and then click the Specify Value button.
In the pop-up window, in the Positive Error Value box, enter the range of values in the Upper limit row in the table we created (or click and drag to select those values). Click OK and then Close.

Now repeat this error bar exercise for the bottom box in the columns, except choose Minus error bars, and enter the range of values in the Lower limit row of our table into the Negative Error Value box.

Right-click on the top box in one of the columns and choose Format Data Series. In the pop-up window, choose Fill on the left, and specify No fill. Then choose Border Color on the left and specify Solid Line.
Repeat for the middle box in the columns.
Repeat for the bottom box in the columns, except this time specify No fill and No line. This will cause the bottom box to simply disappear.
Click on the legend and hit the Delete key to remove it.
Finally, click on the horizontal lines in the background of the graph and hit the Delete key to remove them.

alternative.p: Since we will continue working with the data in the worksheet, it is a good idea to save a copy of your boxplot graph so that when you re-sort the data in the worksheet it does not disappear:

ul.li: Right-click on the graph and choose Copy. Then right-click on an empty cell in the worksheet and choose Paste Special and click OK in the pop-up window. This saves your graph as an image so that it will not be disturbed by re-sorting the data. You can now delete your original graph.
Either clear any equations you may have in your calculator by choosing Y=/CLEAR, or else toggle them off by choosing Y= and then pressing the left arrow until = is selected and pressing ENTER.
Choose STAT PLOT (2ND/Y=).
Choose 4:PlotsOff. Hit ENTER.
Again, choose STAT PLOT (2ND/Y=).
Choose one of the available plots. For example, choose 1:Plot1…Off.
Turn the plot ON by using arrows to highlight the word ON, then press ENTER.
Choose the Type: the fourth graph is a modified boxplot. Using the down arrow will move down to Xlist.

You can display up to 3 boxplots on one screen by turning on three Stat Plots (do this for L4 and AGE3). Once you’ve got all the boxplots turned on, you can ZOOM/9:ZoomStat to see all boxplots on the same screen.

Choose the correct Xlist:
To access one of the built-in lists, such as L1, press 2ND/ 1 (e.g., for the age for individuals in treatment 1).
To access a list you named, use the LIST menu. Press 2nd/LIST/NAMES/ choose appropriate list.
Choose Freq: 1 (the number one).
Choose the Mark you prefer.
You should see:
To view the boxplot, choose ZOOM/9: ZoomStat.

If you want to change the viewing window, choose WINDOW and set Xmin, Xmax, Xscl (the distance between tick marks on the X axis), Ymin, Ymax, Yscl (the distance between tick marks on the Y axis), Xres (leave Xres at 1).
You can choose TRACE and then use the left/right arrows to display minX, Q1, Med, Q3, and maxX.
You can display up to 3 boxplots on one screen by turning on three Stat Plots. Once you’ve got all the boxplots turned on, you can ZOOM/9:ZoomStat to see all boxplots on the same screen.

If you have more than 3 boxplots, plot 2 or 3 at a time, then TRACE and draw a quick sketch of each, paying particular attention to the scale and the 5-number summary. You can ZOOM:9:ZoomStat to see the plots, but to be able to compare them, you have to be sure your sketches are on the same scale.
If you have side-by-side boxplots displayed, you can choose TRACE, then use the up/down arrows to choose one of the boxplots and the left/right arrows to display minX, Q1, Med, Q3, and maxX.

body.p: To compare the distribution of gender among the three treatment groups, we'll look at a two-way table of conditional percents:

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: Copy the following commands to R:

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To do that in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Tables → Contingency → with data
Let Treatment (the explanatory) be the row variable, and Sample(Gender) be the column variable
Display: Row percent
Press Press Compute!

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: In Minitab:

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Tables → Cross Tabulation and Chi-Square.
Let Treatment (the explanatory) be the row variable, and GenderSRS (the response) be the column variable.
Under Display, check Row percents.
Click "OK".

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To create a two-way table in Excel:
First we need to sort our data to make it easier to tabulate:

ul.li: Type Control-A twice to select all of the data in the worksheet.
Choose Sort & Filter → Custom Sort from the Editing group on the Home tab.
In the pop-up window, make sure that My data has headers is selected and then choose Treatment from the pull-down menu next to Sort by.
Click the Add Level button and then choose Gender_SRS from the pull-down menu next to Sort by in the new row that was just added. Click OK.

alternative.p: Now we'll create our two-way table. First we'll make the row and column headings and then use Excel formulas to get the counts:

ul.li: In an empty section of your worksheet, pick a cell and type Statistic. Then move to the right one cell and type Female, move right and type Male, and move right and type Total for our column headings.
For the row headings, start in the cell under Statistic and type Treatment 1, then move down one cell and type Treatment 2, move down and type Treatment 3, and move down and type Total.
Now select the cell under Female and to the right of Treatment 1, and type =counta([range]), where [range] represents the females in the Gender_SRS column that have a Treatment value of 1.

Move one cell to the right (under Male and to the right of Treatment 1) and type =counta([range]), where [range] represents the males in the Gender_SRS column that have a Treatment value of 1. Repeat this for each cell in the table, adjusting the data range appropriately.

To fill in the Total column you can use the sum function. For example, to fill in the cell under total and to the right of Male you could type =sum(F3,G3) where F3 and G3 refer to the counts you calculated for Male and Female from before (your cells may be different based on where you put your table).

Finally, compute the Total for each treatment by adding the numbers in the Male and Female columns. The specific cell references depend on where exactly you created your two-way table, but if D2 represents the number of females in the first treatment group, and E2 represents the total number of males in the first treatment group, the formula would be =D2+E2 .

alternative.p: To create a table of conditional percentages, we'll make a new table underneath the two way-table, and use the same row and column labels as the two-way table:

ul.li: Pick a cell underneath the two-way table, and type the same row and column labels in that we used for the two-way table.

Now select the cell under Female and to the right of Treatment 1. In this cell, we want the percentage of people who are in the first treatment group and are female. Thus, we want to divide the number of females in the first treatment group by the total number of people in the first treatment group, and then multiply by 100 to convert to a percentage. The specific cell references depend on where exactly you created your two-way table, but if D2 represents the number of females in the first treatment group, and F2 represents the total number of people in the first treatment group, the formula would be =(D2/F2)*100.
Calculate the percentages for the other cells in the same manner.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: TI 83/84 calculators do not have the built-in capability to create a two-way table from lists.

This could be a good opportunity to try one of the other technologies available in OLI. We suggest trying R—an excellent statistical package that is free to download and that is available for both Windows and Mac OS X.
If you want to produce a two-way table by hand, you can do so using the lists for Gender1(L2), Gender2 (L5), and Gender3 (list GEND3).

ul.li: Sort each list.
Choose STAT/EDIT/2:SortA(L2)/ENTER.
You should see:
Check out the sorted list by choosing STAT/EDIT.
Using same process, sort Gender2 (L5) and Gender 3 (list GEND3).
Counting:
Count the number of females (1 = Female) and males (2 = Male) in each group. Record it in the table.
Module 2, Case C→C (2 of 2) describes how to create a two-way table with counts and with percentages.

body.p: To compare the distribution of comp (the hours per week of computer use) among the three treatment groups, we'll create side by side boxplots of comp by treatment. Follow the instructions above, making the obvious necessary changes.
Suppose that instead of randomly assigning treatments, the software users could choose one of the three themselves (thus making this an observational study instead of an experiment).
